VI The harmonic oscillator

In quantum mechanics, the harmonic oscillator is an important paradigm because it provides a model for a variety of systems, such as the modes of the electrodynamic field (photons) and the vibrations of molecules and solids (phonons).

VI.1 Classical harmonic oscillator

The classical harmonic oscillator describes a particle subject to a restoring force F=-mâ¢Ï‰2â¢x proportional to the distance from an equilibrium position x=0. Newtonâ€™s equation mâ¢xÂ¨=F results in an oscillatory motion xâ¢(t)=x0â¢cosâ¡Ï‰â¢t+(v0/Ï‰)â¢sinâ¡Ï‰â¢t, where Ï‰=2â¢Ï€/T and T is the oscillation period. In this solution, x0=xâ¢(0) is the initial position and v0=xË™â¢(0) is the initial velocity of the particle. According to F=-Vâ€², the force F=-mâ¢Ï‰2â¢x corresponds to a parabolic potential energy

Vâ¢(x)=12â¢mâ¢Ï‰2â¢x2. (91)

VI.2 SchrÃ¶dinger equation of the quantum harmonic oscillator

In order to solve this problem quantum mechanically, we follow our standard steps. The SchrÃ¶dinger equation of the harmonic oscillator is given by

Eâ¢Ïˆâ¢(x)=-â„22â¢mâ¢Ïˆâ€²â€²â¢(x)+12â¢mâ¢Ï‰2â¢x2â¢Ïˆâ¢(x). (92)

This equation is again a linear differential equation of second order, but now one coefficient is position dependent. From our general considerations we already can anticipate the following:

  • â€¢

    The solutions Ïˆâ¢(x) are continuous.

  • â€¢

    The derivatives Ïˆâ€²â¢(x) of the solutions are also continuous.

  • â€¢

    As Vâ¢(x)â†’âˆ for |x|â†’âˆ, the particle cannot escape to infinity at finite energy E. This only permits bound states, which decay Ïˆâ¢(x)â†’0 as |x|â†’âˆ.

  • â€¢

    The energies of the bound states are discrete (i.e., only at certain energies we can find valid solutions of the SchrÃ¶dinger equation).

  • â€¢

    The ground state energy E0 will be larger than the classical minimal energy: E0>0.

VI.3 Mathematical solution

Let us first focus on finding the mathematical solutions of the SchrÃ¶dinger equation. We start by bringing the SchrÃ¶dinger equation into a simpler, rescaled form. Denote Ïˆâ¢(x)=Ï†â¢(xâ¢mâ¢Ï‰/â„), which corresponds to a rescaled position y=xâ¢mâ¢Ï‰/â„. According to the chain rule, Ïˆâ€²=mâ¢Ï‰/â„â¢Ï†â€² and Ïˆâ€²â€²=(mâ¢Ï‰/â„)â¢Ï†â€²â€². For Îµ=2â¢n+1, n=0,1,2,â€¦, however, Eq.Â (95) has simple solutions fâ¢(y)=Hnâ¢(y) which are just polynomials of degree n. These polynomials are known as the Hermite polynomials. The first two of these polynomials are simply H0=1 and H1=2â¢y. The other polynomials can be calculated recursively, Hn+1â¢(y)=2â¢yâ¢Hnâ¢(y)-2â¢nâ¢Hn-1â¢(y).

VI.4 Ground state and first excited state

The first two solutions correspond to the ground state and the first excited state of the harmonic oscillator:

Ground state: n=0, f=1, which gives to fâ€²=fâ€²â€²=0. This is a solution of Eq.Â (95) if Ïµ=1, which corresponds to an energy E0=12â¢â„â¢Ï‰. The wave function is given by

Ïˆ0â¢(x)=c0â¢expâ¡(-x2â¢mâ¢Ï‰2â¢â„),

VI.5 Normalisation of the ground state wave function

The ground state wave function of the harmonic oscillator provides us with a good occasion to practice once more the normalisation of the wave function. Since we want to interpret |Ïˆ0â¢(x)|2=Pâ¢(x) as the probability density for position, we require
